awd_titl_txt: Shape and Deformation of Colloidal Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support the development of the theoretical framework for the design and control of colloidal membranes. Colloidal membranes are made of filamentous viruses and held together by osmotic forces from polymers in solution. Like cell membranes, colloidal membranes self-assemble; in other words, these membranes form spontaneously from a solution of just the right concentration of rod-like viruses and polymers. Although colloidal membranes resist bending like a solid plate, they also flow like a liquid. Unlike an orange peel, a colloidal membrane shaped like a spherical cap can conform to a flat surface without tearing because the material can redistribute by flowing. Likewise, holes can heal because the material flows. Self-assembly and the ability to easily reconfigure make colloidal membranes attractive for developing artificial micron-scale materials with life-like properties. The focus of this grant is to mathematically model the shape-changing processes using tools from applied mathematics, mechanical engineering, and physics. This grant will support the scientific training of undergraduate and graduate students. The investigators will mentor undergraduates from historically underrepresented groups in engineering and physical science through the Leadership Alliance Summer Research Early Identification Program. Soft matter topics related to this work will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses in engineering and physics. Graduate students will receive training in presentation and communication skills, and develop YouTube videos explaining soft matter topics to the general public.

The specific goal of this research is to apply continuum mechanics techniques to the study of colloidal membranes composed of mixtures of long and short rods in the presence of polymers which hold the rods together via the depletion force. Previous efforts have focused on flat membranes or membrane ribbons composed of a single kind of rod. Membranes consisting of a mixture of rods typically display a rich variety of complex three-dimensional shapes, and the emerging evidence is that many of these shapes are neither minimal surfaces nor constant mean curvature shapes. The shapes can be tuned by controlling experimental conditions such as polymer depletant concentration, and the theory the team will develop will quantitatively determine how shape depends on experimental conditions. The particular aims are to (1) determine how the Gaussian curvature modulus depends on the concentration of short rods as well as the concentration of depleting polymers, (2) determine the conditions that lead to tilting of the constituent rods of the membrane away from the normal to the mid-surface in the bulk of the membrane, and (3) develop a Monte Carlo technique that incorporates  the rod degrees of freedom together with the shape degrees of freedom.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit

Colloidal membranes, composed of rod-like viruses held together by osmotic forces, are fascinating self-assembled structures that mimic some properties of biological membranes but operate on a larger, slower scale. This makes them ideal for exploring fundamental questions about elasticity, chirality, and the stability and dynamics of the shapes that are also exhibited by biological membranes. In this project, we used theory, computer simulations, and experimental collaborations to unravel the physics underlying these systems, revealing how their unique properties give rise to strikingly complex shapes and behaviors.

Our studies showed that changes in simple parameters of the colloidal membrane system can lead to surprising deformations. For instance, our collaborations with experimentalists showed that membranes made of a mixture of rods of two different lengths---i.e. multicomponent membranes---transform into intricate saddle-like structures, balancing the energy costs of surface bending and edge formation. These shapes are reminiscent of minimal surfaces in mathematics and point to new ways to design microns-sized structures with controllable topologies.

Chirality, or the breaking of mirror symmetry, adds another layer of complexity. Due to the spiral arrangement of the proteins in the viral coat, nearby constituent rods tend to twist relative to each other, always in the same sense. One of the key findings of our research came from a computational exploration of the deformation and orientational order of single component colloidal membranes with free edges. We simulated the liquid crystalline order of rod-like viruses within the membrane, which can adopt various configurations depending on the strength of the chiral coupling---i.e. the tendency of the rods to twist with a certain handedness---and the energy cost of tilting the rods relative to the membrane’s surface. Our simulations revealed a phase diagram with distinct membrane shapes and liquid crystalline phases. In particular, we showed that the intrinsic desire of the rods to twist can induce a saddle-like deformation in single-component membranes, in a mechanism that is distinct from the way that the multicomponent membrane saddles formed in our experimental collaboration. In a follow-up study, our numerical computations predicted that as the intrinsic twist between neighboring increases, they can form not just saddles but also catenoids and trinoids.

We also used theoretical modeling to examine the shape of axisymmetric membranes with edges under external forces. This work focused on how membranes, constrained to a constant area, deform when subjected to forces between two boundary rings. This problem is the analog of the classic problem of determining the shape of a soap film on a wire frame. We discovered a rich variety of shapes, including cylindrical tethers and buckled surfaces, with the classic soap-film (catenoid) shape emerging as a critical solution at the maximal separation between rings. This research advances our understanding of buckling instabilities in fluid membranes and their mechanical stability, which is crucial for applications ranging from biological membranes to engineered materials.

Finally, a recent preprint (2024) explores the assembly and disassembly of colloidosomes—micron-sized analogs of lipid vesicles. The experiments of our collaborators revealed how these liquid shells undergo topological transformations, from boundary-free vesicles to one-boundary disks, through an intermediate cylinder-like structure. Our theoretical and computational studies showed why this pathway is the preferred one. The findings offer a detailed view of the topology-changing processes involved in colloidosome formation and disassembly, which have broad implications for nanoparticle filtration, encapsulation, and drug delivery.

Together, these findings reveal the intricate interplay of geometry, elasticity, and chirality in colloidal membranes. They deepen our understanding of soft matter systems and open pathways for designing responsive materials with tunable properties.

Broader Impacts

This project provided hands-on training for five students: three Ph.D. candidates---one in engineering and two in physics (including one from an underrepresented group in physics), one master's student in physics, and one undergraduate in applied mathematics. Two Ph.D. students have already graduated, with one pursuing a career in the semiconductor industry and the other at a national lab. The Master’s student has also joined the scientific workforce in the U.S. defense industry.  The undergraduate student is now enrolled in a doctoral program in geophysics.

Our research also enriched graduate education at Brown University by contributing to the graduate courses Soft Matter and Statistical Mechanics. Additionally, results were disseminated widely through publications, conferences, and seminars, engaging the scientific community and fostering interdisciplinary collaboration.

Beyond advancing fundamental science, this project supported the development of future STEM leaders, underscoring how curiosity-driven research can address challenges at the intersection of biology, physics, and materials science.
